title: Marco Anariba
text:
Marco Antonio Anariba Zelaya (born 18 February 1968) is a retired Honduran <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player who made his name with the national team in the early 1990s.
Club career.
Nicknamed "Maco", Anariba made his debut for <a href="Real%20C.D.%20Espa%C3%B1a">Real España</a> in 1985 and spent 11 years with them. He scored 2 goals for the club in a <a href="1991%20CONCACAF%20Champions%27%20Cup">1991 CONCACAF Champions' Cup</a> game against Belizean outfit <a href="Verdes%20FC">Acros Verdes</a>. He also played for Honduran clubs <a href="C.D.%20Motagua">Motagua</a> for whom he scored 3 goals and <a href="Pumas%20UNAH">Universidad</a>.
In 1990, Anariba was set to join Mexican side <a href="Santos%20Laguna">Santos Laguna</a> but newly appointed Honduran coach <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20de%20la%20Paz%20Herrera">"Chelato Uclés"</a> signed compatriot <a href="Tom%C3%A1s%20R%C3%B3chez">Tomás Róchez</a> instead to join a team including <a href="Eugenio%20Dolmo%20Flores">Eugenio Dolmo Flores</a> and <a href="Luis%20Enrique%20C%C3%A1lix">Luis "Gavilán" Cálix</a>.
He retired at 30.
International career.
A left-sided defender, Anariba made his debut for <a href="Honduras%20national%20football%20team">Honduras</a> in a May <a href="1991%20UNCAF%20Nations%20Cup">1991 UNCAF Nations Cup</a> match against <a href="Panama%20national%20football%20team">Panama</a> and has earned a total of 25 caps, scoring 3 goals. He has represented his country in 10 <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">FIFA World Cup qualification</a> matches and played at the <a href="1991%20UNCAF%20Nations%20Cup">1991</a> and <a href="1993%20UNCAF%20Nations%20Cup">1993 UNCAF Nations Cup</a>s as well as at the <a href="1991%20CONCACAF%20Gold%20Cup">1991 CONCACAF Gold Cup</a>.
His final international was a May 1993 <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification">FIFA World Cup qualification</a> match against <a href="El%20Salvador%20national%20football%20team">El Salvador</a>.
Personal life.
Anariba is married to Waldina, who is a lawyer, and lives in El Progreso where he runs a football school. In summer 2010, he got injured in a veteran league match and after he was treated by a doctor he suffered from thrombosis. His health deteriorated due to the medical malpractice and was bedridden for 30 days, the blood clots almost cost him his left leg. Real España later played a match to raise funds to cover his medical costs.
His brother Juan Manuel also played for Real España.
